title: 110_hr785
content: The Act is titled the "Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2007." It establishes an Inspector General for the Judicial Branch under Part III of title 28, United States Code. The "Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2007" establishes the Office of Inspector General for the Judicial Branch. The Inspector General is appointed by the Chief Justice of the United States for a four-year term, with the possibility of reappointment for additional terms. The Inspector General can be removed from office. The Inspector General for the Judicial Branch can be removed by the Chief Justice of the United States, who must provide reasons for the removal to Congress. The Office's duties include conducting investigations of misconduct, audits, detecting fraud, and recommending changes in laws. The Inspector General has the power to make investigations and reports. The Inspector General has the power to conduct investigations, obtain information from various agencies, subpoena witnesses and documents, and administer oaths. The Inspector General has the authority to employ officers and employees, obtain services at specified rates, and enter into contracts for audits and studies as necessary. The Inspector General has the authority to make necessary payments and conduct investigations under specific conditions. They are limited in investigating decisions or rulings by judges and courts and are required to report annually to the Chief Justice and Congress on the Office's activities. The Inspector General is required to make prompt reports to the Chief Justice and Congress on relevant matters. If a report contains sensitive information, it may be received in closed session. The Inspector General must report promptly to the Attorney General if there is a belief of a violation of Federal criminal law. Whistleblower protection is ensured in the Judicial Branch to prevent discrimination against employees for lawful acts. Whistleblower protection in the Judicial Branch allows employees to provide information on violations of Federal law or misconduct by judges or other employees, assisting the Inspector General. Injured employees can seek relief through civil action. The Inspector General for the Judicial Branch oversees whistleblower protection and investigates violations of Federal law or misconduct by judges and employees.
